class.name: BuoyancyMaterial
class.brief_description: Resource containing buoyancy physics properties for a body interacting with a [LiquidArea].
class.description: [BuoyancyMaterial] holds the physical properties that control how an object behaves when submerged in a [LiquidArea]. Attach it to a [Buoyancy] or [CharacterBuoyancy] node to define buoyancy strength and drag characteristics. The [member buoyancy] scalar controls how much of the object's weight is countered by buoyant force. A value of [code]1.0[/code] means neutral buoyancy (the object displaces exactly its own weight in fluid), [code]0.0[/code] means no buoyant force (sinks), and values greater than [code]1.0[/code] cause the object to float. Drag properties control how quickly the body decelerates while submerged. Linear drag affects translational velocity and angular drag affects rotational velocity. Per-axis scaling allows asymmetric drag, for example making a boat resist lateral movement more than forward movement.

members.member: Buoyancy scalar controlling how much the object floats. A value of [code]0.0[/code] disables buoyant force (object sinks), [code]1.0[/code] is neutral buoyancy, and values greater than [code]1.0[/code] cause the object to float. Only used when [member Buoyancy.use_buoyancy_scalar] is enabled on the parent [Buoyancy] node.
Linear velocity drag coefficient applied while the body is submerged. Higher values cause more rapid deceleration in water. Multiplied by [member linear_drag_scale] to produce per-axis drag.
Angular velocity drag coefficient applied while the body is submerged. Higher values cause more rapid rotational damping in water. Multiplied by [member angular_drag_scale] to produce per-axis drag.

Per-axis scaling for linear drag in body-local space. Multiplied with [member linear_drag] to control drag independently on each axis. For example, setting Z higher increases drag when moving forward/backward.
Per-axis scaling for angular drag in body-local space. Multiplied with [member angular_drag] to control rotational damping independently on each axis.
